meeting_annotations.speaker: Sara L. Zimmer (U of Minn) she/her
meeting_annotations.transcript: That might be too hard for the first year.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linda Detwiler, USDA, APHIS, VS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, thank you. Okay, Tavis, you have your hand up here and then I'm going to kind of try and bring us to to some kind of, yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tavis Anderson (USDA-ARS)
meeting_annotations.transcript: You're going to massage us into one cohesive unit.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linda Detwiler, USDA, APHIS, VS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, at least for the report, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tavis Anderson (USDA-ARS)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah. Um, I think Hannah is responsible for that, so.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Hannah Frank Tulane (she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I've mostly just been acting as a stenographer, but I'm trying to do some synthesis.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tavis Anderson (USDA-ARS)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, geez, that that that's tricky. Um, so I was thinking here, like if you just looked at a like a checkerboard, right? That checkerboard um exists across all of the special scales that we're talking about. Uh and then there could be different things taken at each at each spatial scale and at each of those scales we could run file dynamic analysis as well. So in Justin's web for example, or with collaborators here, we can take an individual Petri dish that's made up of a layer of cells and infect that layer of cells and then sequence everything that is within that cell, that that cell layer and then do phylogenetics on that. And a broader scale then we can look at individual animals and and do sequencing during the course of infection and look at phylodynamics there across the herd and then across populations and scale there um with a targeted study. Uh and then look at each of those levels, try and control predictive variables that we believe are are important in driving the evolutionary dynamics of these viruses. So within individual Petri dishes we could do a heat wave treatment or a nutrient limitation treatment. Somebody mentioned energy limitation in one of the their studies, I think it might have been Sarah. You know the idea we've got there an Eltonian pyramid, right? Where you've got restriction of energy all the way up and then viruses and bacteria filtering off that energy at different traffic levels. But the the idea would be that we could manipulate abiotic environments at each of those different spatial scales and then have targeted sequencing at each of those scales as well and track the evolutionary dynamics with the prediction that at particular time points there's going to be these clouds of variants that uh can emerge and spill over and cause pandemics.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linda Detwiler, USDA, APHIS, VS
meeting_annotations.transcript: So what do you all think?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tavis Anderson (USDA-ARS)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm saying that as as a computational person who would love to analyze all of that data, but I also don't do plaque purification in the lab and I don't extract individual virus isolates and sequence them. I just work with the data.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linda Detwiler, USDA, APHIS, VS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well Adela has her hand up, so maybe.

meeting_annotations.speaker: adela
meeting_annotations.transcript: So what I was going to say that the only problem though, we'll see with that is that it is known that when you do things in vitro, they do not translate to what happens in vivo. Uh, for example, like what happens a lot in vitro is that you're going to actually select for a specific virus or like specific strain that is really good at growing in that particular in vitro system and then when you try to go and infect a mosquito, the mosquito doesn't become infected.

meeting_annotations.speaker: adela
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, so I don't know if an in vitro system is the best solution for looking at that. I would think that using animals or like in vivo systems would be better.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Tavis Anderson (USDA-ARS)
meeting_annotations.transcript: But that might also reveal something like Sarah was saying with his bacteria, right? The the context is important for the emergence of these vibrio as pathogens, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linda Detwiler, USDA, APHIS, VS

meeting_annotations.transcript: You can look.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)

meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, I agree. I and and so when I study viruses, I compare those genes, I'm learning about the host. Uh, but I I wonder then if uh if there's a way to actually just predict a whole bunch of different epitopes for different pathogens that we think are are potential uh to uh to infect humans, then teaming up with an immunologist that can help us interpret that data to say, look, these these impact these pathways, these may impact. Other ones, here's ones that need to be experimentally tested, potentially could and then work with the theoretician to say, you know, now we got some information about the host based on what we see from the from the viral sequence. meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, and I I I'm going to we're going to have to kind of pull this. We just got the 10 minute warning. Adela, you still have your hand up. Did you want to make a final comment before we start to pull stuff together or?
